prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Fragmentation, l=200-210
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Identification and mapping of small scale structures inside clumps in the Outer Galaxy. Range considered: galactic longitude 200 - 210 deg 4 basebands: 1 for continuum, 1 for CO(2-1), 1 for 13CO(2-1), and 1 for C18O(2-1) Resolution of 0.3 arcsec, and maximuum recovery of 4 arcsec. Sensitivity requested: 0.2 mJy/beam for the continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The bandwidth of 1875 MHz is considered only for obtaining the continuum of the line, and therefore we consider a wide frequency spacing beacuse we do not expect to follow a line analisys in this bandwidth. For the other basebands, we consider a wide of 300 km/s, which allow to detect a widening of lines (if any), and the resolution of 0.2 km/s allows the good characterization of the line emission, even the narrow lines (in comparison with othe line emision on fragmentation of cores, e.g. Palau et al 2013). A spectral average of 2 was considered for the baseband of the lines to avoid an excedding data rate. The 300 km/s also allows the shift on 13CO and CO to set a correct configuration and map those lines simultaneously

The field of view of ALMA interferometer is similar to the Herschel PSF at 250 um. We are looking for the smallest cores in each clump, concentrating in this band in the very dense and compact substructures within the clumps, in both dust emission, and line observations with kinematic only related to those structures and not the harboring clump. Therefore 3.5-4 arcsec is enough for the largest scale planed for recovery. Following other interferometric works (e.g. Palau et al 2013), we aim to obtain a resolution of 0.2-0.3 arcsec. We consider a resolution of 0.3 arcsec because: (1) Allow the recovery of structures of 0.0015 - 0.013 pc in the distance range 1 - 9 kpc of this proposal. This sizes are considered less than clump scales, more related with core / condensations within cores scales. (2) The combination of res 0.3 arcsec and MRS of 3.5 arcsec allows that two ALMA configurations are suitable for the observations: C36-4 and C36-5, which could make more flexible scheduling the observations.

We request a bandwidth of 1875 Mhz, centerd at 233 GHz, to obtain the continuum emission at ~1.2 mm. We located this baseband at that frequency because of the lack of strong contamining molecular lines. Adittional baseband are centered at the C18O lines, and the baseband associated to the baseband 13CO(2-1) and CO(2-1) are centered at 220.338 GHz and 230.59 GHz, which gives a shift of ~ 70 km/s, but in agreement with the configuration (we do not expect very wide lines). We aim to observe a mass sensitivity of 0.4 Msun at 3kpc, or what is the same 0.004 - 0.3 Msun at 1 - 9 kpc range, requiring a continuum sensitivity of ~0.2 mJy/beam at 4sigma over the 1875 MHz bandwidth, which was used for time estimations. This sensitivity is enough for detection of the other lines in the band. For example, RADEX estimation of dense object (~10^4 cm-3, column density of 1e23 cm-2, assuming a line width of 5 km/s (estimated from a virial analysis), gives a peak temperature of 5 even for a cold object (T=10 K).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Tracing infalling material l=200-210
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Study of lines HCO+, HCN, H13CO+, H13CN Infalling motions within dense clumps Range considered: galactic longitude 200 - 210 deg 4 basebands: 4 1/2 with lines, 1 for CS, 1 for H2CO Resolution of 3 arcsec, and maximuum recovery of 4 arcsec. Sensitivity requested: 0.06 K for H13CO+

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The division of sidebands permits to map both infalling motion tracers HCO+ and HCN. Although conveninent, this limits the bandwidth for them to 200 km/s, which is enough to trace infalling profiles when comparing with previous studies (e.g. Rygl et al. 2013). We consider the highest velocity resolution, with an spectral average of 2 to avoid high data rates. Then, the velocity resolution of 0.24 km/s is enough for the detection of the FWHM of the structures in the optically thin lines of H13CO+ and H13CN. Additional lines, CS and H2CO mapped on the other band, are considered as secondary objectives, so a bandwidth of 468 MHz was considered for them, with a velocity resolution of 1.5 km/s after a spectral average of 4. This last bandwidth and resolution was considered for avoiding non-standard observation modes with a more narrow band, and to avoid high data rates.

We aim for a resolution of 2 arcsec, which corresponds to a physical size of 0.01 - 0.09 pc, reaching to core scale sizes even for the targets at large distances. The maximum recovery scale results important, because the aim of this science goal is the study of the kinematics of clumps and possible infalling motions into their substructures, as a possible sign of dynamical collapse of massive gas clumps. The requested largest angular scale of 24 arcsec is on the order or larger than the clump sizes. Band 3 is the only one with a configuration that recovers structures with an angular scale comparable with the resolution of the submillimeter bands of Herschel.

We aim for observing the pair of lines HCO+ and HCN, and their optically thin isotopes H13CO+ and H13CN. Those pair of lines (HCO+/H13CO+ and HCN/H13CN) have been used in previous studies for determing in infalling motions. To put in the context of a similar study by Rygl et al. (2013), observations of H13CO+ should have a 1-sigma rms of at least 0.06 K. We note that using the transfer code RADEX, considering a dense source with n~10^4 cm^-3, and column density of 10^20 cm^-2, the emission estimated for the H13CO+(1-0) is 7 K (for a cold source T~10 K), which is the same as 390 mJy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Tracing infalling material l=280-290
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Study of lines HCO+, HCN, H13CO+, H13CN Infalling motions within dense clumps Range considered: galactic longitude 280 - 290 deg 4 basebands: 4 1/2 with lines, 1 for CS, 1 for H2CO Resolution of 3 arcsec, and maximuum recovery of 4 arcsec. Sensitivity requested: 0.06 K for H13CO+

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The division of sidebands permits to map both infalling motion tracers HCO+ and HCN. Although conveninent, this limits the bandwidth for them to 200 km/s, which is enough to trace infalling profiles when comparing with previous studies (e.g. Rygl et al. 2013). We consider the highest velocity resolution, with an spectral average of 2 to avoid high data rates. Then, the velocity resolution of 0.24 km/s is enough for the detection of the FWHM of the structures in the optically thin lines of H13CO+ and H13CN. Additional lines, CS and H2CO mapped on the other band, are considered as secondary objectives, so a bandwidth of 468 MHz was considered for them, with a velocity resolution of 1.5 km/s after a spectral average of 4. This last bandwidth and resolution was considered for avoiding non-standard observation modes with a more narrow band, and to avoid high data rates.

We aim for a resolution of 3 arcsec, which corresponds to a physical size of 0.015 - 0.13 pc for distances between 1 - 9 kpc, reaching to core scale sizes even for the targets at large distances. The maximum recovery scale results important, because the aim of this science goal is the study of the kinematics of clumps and possible infalling motions into their substructures, as a possible sign of dynamical collapse of massive gas clumps. The requested largest angular scale of 24 arcsec is on the order or larger than the clump sizes. Band 3 is the only one with a configuration that recovers structures with an angular scale comparable with the resolution of the submillimeter bands of Herschel, without using the ACA array.

We aim for observing the pair of lines HCO+ and HCN, and their optically thin isotopes H13CO+ and H13CN. Those pair of lines (HCO+/H13CO+ and HCN/H13CN) have been used in previous studies for determing in infalling motions. To put in the context of a similar study by Rygl et al. (2013), observations of H13CO+ should have a 1-sigma rms of at least 0.06 K. We note that using the transfer code RADEX, considering a dense source with n~10^4 cm^-3, and column density of 10^20 cm^-2, the emission estimated for the H13CO+(1-0) is 7 K (for a cold source T~10 K).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to carry out a first representative study of global infall and its influence on fragmentation for a Herschel-selected sample of 48 high-mass (M>100M sun) and high surface density (>0.1 g/cm-2) clumps in the Outer Galaxy. The sample spans the evolutionary path from infrared-quiet clumps with no or very low rate of star formation, to infrared bright and actively star forming clumps with Lbol/Menv ratio up to 100, typical of UltraCompact HII regions. This will be the first systematic characterization of fragmentation and infall properties of high-mass dense clumps in the relatively unexplored Outer Galaxy regions (170<l<290), providing, in the context of similar ongoing studies in the inner Galaxy, an invaluable benchmark to trace the relative importance of the different agents regulating high-mass star formation as a function of Galactocentric radius.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: "Fragmentation in Hi-GAL clumps ", PI: M. Pestalozzi

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Jodrell Bank Centre for Astrophysics, Manchester, University of
Institute of Radioastronomy of Bologna, INAF
